{"uri": "2024-05-374237559", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "09:02:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T09:02:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T08:59:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/us-britain-houthi-yemen-shipping-attacks-9363470/", "title": "US and Britain strike Houthi rebel targets in Yemen after surge in shipping attacks | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "The Houthi rebels said the airstrikes killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others\n\nThe US and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden over the Israel-Hamas war, three US officials said.\n\nThe Houthi rebels said the airstrikes killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others. According to the officials, American and British fighter jets and US ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the US were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe Houthis' Al Masirah satellite news station highlighted one of the strikes, which hit a radio building in the Red City port city of Hodeida. It aired images of one bloodied man being carried down stairs and others receiving treatment at a hospital. Other strikes hit outside of the rebel-held capital, Sanaa, near its airport and communication equipment in Taiz, the broadcaster said.\n\nAlso read | Yemen's Houthis say they launch attacks on 3 ships including one in Mediterranean\n\nLittle other information was released -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\n\"We confirm this brutal aggression against Yemen as punishment for its position in support of Gaza, in support of Israel to continue its crimes of genocide against the wounded, besieged and steadfast Gaza Strip,\" Houthi spokesman Mohammed Abdulsalam wrote on the social platform X.\n\nThe strikes came a day after a US MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It was the third such downing in May alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. The Houthis have claimed responsibility for the attack. This is the fifth time that the U.S. and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12.\n\nBut the US also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch. The U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other US warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nAlso read | Israel moves deeper into Rafah and fights Hamas militants regrouping in northern Gaza\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the US Maritime Administration. Shipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat. US warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nAlso read | Houthis launch attacks on 3 ships, 2 US destroyers in nearby seas, group says\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the US won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. But the counterattacks haven't appeared to diminish the Houthis' campaign against shipping in the region.", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Indian Express"}, {"uri": "8155190881", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "13:20:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T13:20:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T13:19:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.tribtoday.com/news/latest-news/2024/05/us-and-britain-strike-houthi-rebel-targets-in-yemen-after-surge-in-shipping-attacks/", "title": "US and Britain strike Houthi rebel targets in Yemen after surge in shipping attacks", "body": "A Houthi soldier stands alert on board of the Israeli Galaxy ship which was seized by the Houthis, in the port of Saleef, near Hodeidah, Yemen, Sunday, May. 12, 2024. (AP Photo/Osamah Abdulrahman)\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- The U.S. and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden over the Israel-Hamas war, three U.S. officials said. The Houthi rebels said the airstrikes killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others.\n\nAccording to the officials, American and British fighter jets and U.S. ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the U.S. were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe Houthis' Al Masirah satellite news station highlighted one of the strikes, which hit a radio building in the Red City port city of Hodeida. It aired images of one bloodied man being carried down stairs and others receiving treatment at a hospital.\n\nOther strikes hit outside of the rebel-held capital, Sanaa, near its airport and communication equipment in Taiz, the broadcaster said. Little other information was released -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\n\"We confirm this brutal aggression against Yemen as punishment for its position in support of Gaza, in support of Israel to continue its crimes of genocide against the wounded, besieged and steadfast Gaza Strip,\" Houthi spokesman Mohammed Abdulsalam wrote on the social platform X.\n\nThe strikes came a day after a U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It was the third such downing in May alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. The Houthis have claimed responsibility for the attack.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the U.S. and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12. But the U.S. also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other U.S. warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nU.S. warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the U.S. won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. But the counterattacks haven't appeared to diminish the Houthis' campaign against shipping in the region.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Jon Gambrell in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, contributed.", {"uri": "8154691537", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "08:04:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T08:04:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T08:02:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.etvbharat.com/en/!international/us-and-britain-strike-houthi-rebel-targets-in-yemen-after-surge-in-shipping-attacks-enn24053100340", "title": "US and Britain Strike Houthi Rebel Targets in Yemen after Surge in Shipping Attacks", "body": "Washington: The U.S. and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden over the Israel-Hamas war, three U.S. officials said. The Houthi rebels said the airstrikes killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others.\n\nAccording to the officials, American and British fighter jets and U.S. ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the U.S. were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe Houthis' Al Masirah satellite news station highlighted one of the strikes, which hit a radio building in the Red City port city of Hodeida. It aired images of one bloodied man being carried down stairs and others receiving treatment at a hospital.\n\nOther strikes hit outside of the rebel-held capital, Sanaa, near its airport and communication equipment in Taiz, the broadcaster said. Little other information was released -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\n\"We confirm this brutal aggression against Yemen as punishment for its position in support of Gaza, in support of Israel to continue its crimes of genocide against the wounded, besieged and steadfast Gaza Strip,\" Houthi spokesman Mohammed Abdulsalam wrote on the social platform X.\n\nThe strikes came a day after a U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It was the third such downing in May alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. The Houthis have claimed responsibility for the attack.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the U.S. and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12. But the U.S. also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other U.S. warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nU.S. warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the U.S. won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. But the counterattacks haven't appeared to diminish the Houthis' campaign against shipping in the region.", "source": {"uri": "etvbharat.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ETV Bharat News"}, {"uri": "8154659657", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "07:42:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T07:42:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T07:39:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/us-and-britain-strike-houthi-rebel-targets-in-yemen-after-surge-in-shipping-attacks/article_ed84a4fc-f8f5-52ba-960e-159e8aae5af6.html", "title": "US and Britain strike Houthi rebel targets in Yemen after surge in shipping attacks", "body": "British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak issues a statement after British and US forces struck Houthi targets in Yemen, at 10 Downing Street, London, Friday May 31, 2024. The U.S. and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden over the Israel-Hamas war.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- The U.S. and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden over the Israel-Hamas war, three U.S. officials said. The Houthi rebels said the airstrikes killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others.\n\nAccording to the officials, American and British fighter jets and U.S. ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the U.S. were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe Houthis' Al Masirah satellite news station highlighted one of the strikes, which hit a radio building in the Red City port city of Hodeida. It aired images of one bloodied man being carried down stairs and others receiving treatment at a hospital.\n\nOther strikes hit outside of the rebel-held capital, Sanaa, near its airport and communication equipment in Taiz, the broadcaster said. Little other information was released -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\n\"We confirm this brutal aggression against Yemen as punishment for its position in support of Gaza, in support of Israel to continue its crimes of genocide against the wounded, besieged and steadfast Gaza Strip,\" Houthi spokesman Mohammed Abdulsalam wrote on the social platform X.\n\nThe strikes came a day after a U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It was the third such downing in May alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. The Houthis have claimed responsibility for the attack.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the U.S. and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12. But the U.S. also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other U.S. warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nU.S. warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the U.S. won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. But the counterattacks haven't appeared to diminish the Houthis' campaign against shipping in the region.\n\nAssociated Press writer Jon Gambrell in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, contributed.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@eagletribune.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "lolita_c_baldor@eagletribune.com", "name": "Lolita C. {"uri": "8154506744", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "05:45:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T05:45:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T05:45:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://english.aawsat.com/node/5026168", "title": "US and Britain Strike Houthi Targets in Yemen after Surge in Shipping Attacks", "body": "A Houthi military helicopter flies over a cargo ship in the Red Sea. (Reuters)\n\nThe US and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, three US officials said.\n\nAccording to the officials, American and British fighter jets and US ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the US were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe Houthis' Al Masirah satellite news said at least two people were killed and 10 others were wounded in one of the strikes, which hit a radio building in the Red City port city of Hodeida. It aired images of one bloodied man being carried down stairs and others receiving treatment at a hospital. Other strikes hit outside of the Houthi-held capital, Sanaa, and elsewhere in the country, with little other information being released -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\nThe strikes came a day after a US MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It was the third such downing this month alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. The Houthis have claimed responsibility for the attack.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the US and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12. But the US also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe US F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other US warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the US Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nUS warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the US won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. But the counterattacks haven't appeared to diminish the Houthis' campaign against shipping in the region.", "source": {"uri": "english.aawsat.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Asharq Al-Awsat {"uri": "2024-05-373925565", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "02:50:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T02:50:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T22:40:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://kfdm.com/news/nation-world/us-britain-strike-retaliate-houthi-rebel-targets-yemen-surge-shipping-attacks-iran-backed-militia-group-israel-red-sea-gulf-aden-missiles-fighter-jets-underground-facilities-launchers-command-control-sites-vessel", "title": "US, Britain strike back at Houthi rebel targets in Yemen for surge in shipping attacks", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The U.S. and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, three U.S. officials said.\n\nAccording to the officials, American and British fighter jets and U.S. ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the U.S. were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe Houthis' Al Masirah satellite news said at least two people were killed and 10 others were wounded in one of the strikes, which hit a radio building in the Red City port city of Hodeida. It aired images of one bloodied man being carried down stairs and others receiving treatment at a hospital. Other strikes hit outside of the rebel-held capital, Sanaa, and elsewhere in the country, with little other information being released -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\nThe strikes came a day after a U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It was the third such downing this month alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. The Houthis have claimed responsibility for the attack.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the U.S. and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12. But the U.S. also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other U.S. warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nU.S. warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the U.S. won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. But the counterattacks haven't appeared to diminish the Houthis' campaign against shipping in the region.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "kfdm.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KFDM"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kfdm.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "lolita_c_baldor@kfdm.com", "name": "Lolita C. {"uri": "8154612029", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "07:07:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T07:07:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T07:05:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/305595", "title": "Yemen Houthi rebels' TV says 14 killed in US-British strikes", "body": "A Houthi-run television channel on Friday said 14 people were killed and more than 30 wounded in strikes conducted on Yemen overnight by the United States and Britain.\n\n\"The death toll from the U.S.-British air strikes on the Hodeida radio station and the port of Salif has risen to 14, with more than 30 injured,\" the Iran-backed Yemeni rebels' Al-Masirah station reported.\n\nThe U.S. and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, three U.S. officials said.\n\nAccording to the officials, American and British fighter jets and U.S. ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the U.S. were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe Houthis' Al Masirah satellite news said at least two people were killed and 10 others were wounded in one of the strikes, which hit a radio building in the Red City port city of Hodeida. It aired images of one bloodied man being carried down stairs and others receiving treatment at a hospital. Other strikes hit outside of the rebel-held capital, Sanaa, and elsewhere in the country, with little other information being released -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\nThe strikes came a day after a U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It was the third such downing this month alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. The Houthis have claimed responsibility for the attack.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the U.S. and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12. But the U.S. also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other U.S. warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nU.S. warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the U.S. won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. {"uri": "2024-05-374188909", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "08:18:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T08:18:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T08:06:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.wboc.com/news/international/houthi-rebels-say-at-least-16-killed-35-others-wounded-in-joint-us-british-airstrikes/article_069cd3cf-0f98-56a4-94e1-29ad29fd8ff0.html", "title": "Houthi rebels say at least 16 killed, 35 others wounded in joint US-British airstrikes in Yemen", "body": "British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak issues a statement after British and US forces struck Houthi targets in Yemen, at 10 Downing Street, London, Friday May 31, 2024. The U.S. and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden over the Israel-Hamas war.\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- Joint British-U.S. airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others, the rebels said Friday, the highest publicly acknowledged death toll by the rebels from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over their attacks on shipping.\n\nThree U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity to describe a then-ongoing attack, described the strikes Thursday as hitting a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. They called it a response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden over the Israel-Hamas war.\n\nThe U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets involved in the strikes launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other U.S. warships in the region also participated.\n\nBut the Houthis focused Friday morning on just one of the strikes, which they said struck a building housing Hodeida Radio and civilian homes in the port city on the Red Sea. Their Al Masirah satellite news channel aired images of one bloodied man being carried down stairs and others in the hospital, receiving aid.\n\nThe Houthis described all those killed and hurt in Hodeida as civilians, something The Associated Press could not immediately confirm. The rebel force that's held Yemen's capital, Sanaa, since 2014 includes fighters who often are not in uniform.\n\nOther strikes hit outside of Sanaa near its airport and communication equipment in Taiz, the broadcaster said. Little other information was released on those sites -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\n\"We confirm this brutal aggression against Yemen as punishment for its position in support of Gaza, in support of Israel to continue its crimes of genocide against the wounded, besieged and steadfast Gaza Strip,\" Houthi spokesman Mohammed Abdulsalam wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nIn the United Kingdom, the country's Defense Ministry said Royal Air Force Typhoon FGR4s conducted strikes on both Hodeida and further south in Ghulayfiqah. It described its targets as \"buildings identified as housing drone ground control facilities and providing storage for very long range drones, as well as surface-to-air weapons.\"\n\n\"The strikes were taken in self-defense in the face of an ongoing threat that the Houthis pose,\" British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said. \"There's an ongoing threat that the Houthis pose.\"\n\nThe Houthis ihave stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians there. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking around 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, killed three sailors, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration. This week, they attacked a ship carrying grain to Iran, the rebels' main benefactor.\n\nOn Wednesday, another U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone apparently crashed in Yemen, with the Houthis claiming they fired a surface-to-air missile at it. The U.S. Air Force didn't report any aircraft missing, leading to suspicion that the drone may have been piloted by the CIA. As many as three may have been lost in May alone.\n\nBaldor reported from Washington.", "source": {"uri": "wboc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WBOC TV-16"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@wboc.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "jon_gambrell@wboc.com", "name": "Jon Gambrell", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "lolita_c_baldor@wboc.com", "name": "Lolita C. {"uri": "8154202485", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "00:14:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T00:14:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T00:13:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/us-and-britain-strike-houthi-rebel-targets-in-yemen-after-surge-in-shipping-attacks/FBHIFTZ3ANACXHECTK3IUIGNJQ/", "title": "US and Britain strike 13 Houthi rebel targets", "body": "The US and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, three US officials said.\n\nThey said American and British fighter jets and US ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the US were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe strikes come a day after a US MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It marked the third such downing this month alone.\n\nAlso this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. While no group claimed responsibility, suspicion fell on the Houthis.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the US and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since January 12. But the US also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe US F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other US warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza that has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on October 7, killing about 1200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the US Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nUS warships, meanwhile, took out several missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned the US won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. {"uri": "2024-05-373813737", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "22:52:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T22:52:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T22:52:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://globalnation.inquirer.net/238176/us-britain-strike-houthi-rebel-targets-in-yemen", "title": "US and Britain strike Houthi rebel targets in Yemen", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The United States and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, three US officials said.\n\nAccording to the officials, American and British fighter jets and US ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel, and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the US were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nREAD: US, Britain wage strikes against Iran-linked Houthis in Yemen\n\nThe strikes come a day after a US MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It marked the third such downing this month alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. While no group claimed responsibility, suspicion fell on the Houthis.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the US and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since January 12. But the US also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe US F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other US warships in the region also participated.\n\nREAD: US, Britain carry out strikes vs Houthis in Yemen - officials\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on October 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the US Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nUS warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the US won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. But the counterattacks haven't appeared to diminish the Houthis' campaign against shipping in the region.", "source": {"uri": "globalnation.inquirer.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Inquirer"}, The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the US were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe strikes come a day after a US MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It marked the third such downing this month alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. While no group claimed responsibility, suspicion fell on the Houthis.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the US and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12. But the US also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe US F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other US warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the US Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nUS warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the US won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. {"uri": "8154090281", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "21:56:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T21:56:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T21:55:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2956077-us-britain-strike-back-13-houthi-targets-hit-in-yemen", "title": "US & Britain Strike Back: 13 Houthi Targets Hit in Yemen | Law-Order", "body": "The US and Britain conducted coordinated strikes on 13 Houthi targets in Yemen, responding to increased militia attacks on Red Sea and Gulf of Aden shipping. The offensive involved American and British fighter jets and warships, destroying missile launchers and command sites. The Houthi attacks have intensified in recent months.\n\nThe US and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, three US officials said.\n\nAccording to the officials, American and British fighter jets and US ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the US were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe strikes come a day after a US MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It marked the third such downing this month alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. While no group claimed responsibility, suspicion fell on the Houthis.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the US and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since January 12. But the US also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe US F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other US warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on October 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the US Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nUS warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the US won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. But the counterattacks haven't appeared to diminish the Houthis' campaign against shipping in the region.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a {"uri": "2024-05-373892993", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "01:42:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T01:42:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T01:41:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.ksbw.com/article/us-strike-houthi-rebel-targets-in-yemen/60953561", "title": "US and Britain strike Houthi rebel targets in Yemen after surge in shipping attacks", "body": "The U.S. and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, three U.S. officials said.According to the officials, American and British fighter jets and U.S. ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.Also struck by the U.S. were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.The strikes come a day after a U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It marked the third such downing this month alone.Also earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. While no group claimed responsibility, suspicion fell on the Houthis.This is the fifth time that the U.S. and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12. But the U.S. also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.The U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other U.S. warships in the region also participated.The Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.The Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration.Shipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.U.S. warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.President Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the U.S. won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. But the counterattacks haven't appeared to diminish the Houthis' campaign against shipping in the region.\n\nThe U.S. and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, three U.S. officials said.\n\nAccording to the officials, American and British fighter jets and U.S. ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. While no group claimed responsibility, suspicion fell on the Houthis.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the U.S. and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12. The Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It was the third such downing in May.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen. The Houthis have claimed responsibility for the attack.\n\nThursday's attack is the fifth the US and British militaries have conducted jointly against the Houthis since 12 January. The US also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians.\n\nThe {"uri": "2024-05-374298642", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "09:55:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T09:55:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T08:06:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/05/31/houthi-rebels-say-at-least-16-killed-35-others-wounded-in-joint-us-british-airstrikes-in-yemen/", "title": "Houthi rebels say at least 16 killed, 35 others wounded in joint US-British airstrikes in Yemen", "body": "British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak issues a statement after British and US forces struck Houthi targets in Yemen, at 10 Downing Street, London, Friday May 31, 2024. The U.S. and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group [...]\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- Joint British-U.S. airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others, the rebels said Friday, the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels' attacks on shipping.\n\nThree U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity to describe a then-ongoing attack, described the strikes Thursday as hitting a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. They called it a response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden over the Israel-Hamas war.\n\nThe U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets involved in the strikes launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other U.S. warships in the region also participated.\n\nBut the Houthis focused Friday morning on just one of the strikes, which they said struck a building housing Hodeida Radio and civilian homes in the port city on the Red Sea. Their Al Masirah satellite news channel aired images of one bloodied man being carried down stairs and others in the hospital, receiving aid.\n\nThe Houthis described all those killed and hurt in Hodeida as civilians, something The Associated Press could not immediately confirm. The rebel force that's held Yemen's capital, Sanaa, since 2014 includes fighters who often are not in uniform.\n\nOther strikes hit outside of Sanaa near its airport and communication equipment in Taiz, the broadcaster said. Little other information was released on those sites -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\n\"We confirm this brutal aggression against Yemen as punishment for its position in support of Gaza, in support of Israel to continue its crimes of genocide against the wounded, besieged and steadfast Gaza Strip,\" Houthi spokesman Mohammed Abdulsalam wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nIn the United Kingdom, the country's Defense Ministry said Royal Air Force Typhoon FGR4s conducted strikes on both Hodeida and further south in Ghulayfiqah. It described its targets as \"buildings identified as housing drone ground control facilities and providing storage for very long-range drones, as well as surface-to-air weapons.\"\n\n\"The strikes were taken in self-defense in the face of an ongoing threat that the Houthis pose,\" British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said. \"There's an ongoing threat that the Houthis pose.\"\n\nThe U.S. and the U.K. have launched strikes against the Houthis since January, with the U.S. regularly carrying out its own in the time since as well. Abdul Malik al-Houthi, the Houthis' secretive supreme leader, offered an overall death toll for the strikes up to that point as 40 people killed and 35 others wounded. He did not offer a breakdown between civilian and combatant casualties at the time.\n\nThe Houthis have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians there. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking around 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, killed three sailors, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration. This week, they attacked a ship carrying grain to Iran, the rebels' main benefactor.\n\nOn Wednesday, another U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone apparently crashed in Yemen, with the Houthis claiming they fired a surface-to-air missile at it. The U.S. Air Force didn't report any aircraft missing, leading to suspicion that the drone may have been piloted by the CIA. As many as three may have been lost in May alone.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@tribtown.com", "name": {"uri": "2024-05-373777465", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "21:46:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T21:46:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T17:33:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2024-05-30/us-and-britain-strike-houthi-rebel-targets-in-yemen-after-surge-in-shipping-attacks", "title": "US and Britain Strike Houthi Rebel Targets in Yemen After Surge in Shipping Attacks", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The U.S. and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, three U.S. officials said.\n\nAccording to the officials, American and British fighter jets and U.S. ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the U.S. were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe strikes come a day after a U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It marked the third such downing this month alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. While no group claimed responsibility, suspicion fell on the Houthis.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the U.S. and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12. But the U.S. also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other U.S. warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nU.S. warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the U.S. won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. But the counterattacks haven't appeared to diminish the Houthis' campaign against shipping in the region.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8154319948", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "02:45:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T02:45:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T02:45:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/may/30/us-and-britain-strike-houthi-rebel-targets-in-yeme/", "title": "US and Britain strike Houthi rebel targets in Yemen after surge in shipping attacks", "body": "Etat Major des Armees via A\n\nIn this undated photo provided by the Etat Major des Armees on Thursday, May 30, 2024, a view of the Laax, a Greek-owned, Marshall Islands-flagged bulk carrier that came under attack by Yemen's Houthi rebels earlier this week, carrying cargo of grain bound for Iran, the group's main benefactor, authorities said Thursday.\n\nBy Lolita C. Baldor, Associated Press\n\nThursday, May 30, 2024 | 7:30 p.m.\n\nWASHINGTON -- The U.S. and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, three U.S. officials said.\n\nAccording to the officials, American and British fighter jets and U.S. ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the U.S. were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe Houthis' Al Masirah satellite news said at least two people were killed and 10 others were wounded in one of the strikes, which hit a radio building in the Red City port city of Hodeida. It aired images of one bloodied man being carried down stairs and others receiving treatment at a hospital. Other strikes hit outside of the rebel-held capital, Sanaa, and elsewhere in the country, with little other information being released -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\nThe strikes came a day after a U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It was the third such downing this month alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. The Houthis have claimed responsibility for the attack.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the U.S. and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12. But the U.S. also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other U.S. warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nU.S. warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the U.S. won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. But the counterattacks haven't appeared to diminish the Houthis' campaign against shipping in the region.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Jon Gambrell in Dubai contributed.", "source": {"uri": "lasvegassun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Las Vegas Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@lasvegassun.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}, {"uri": "lolita_c_baldor@lasvegassun.com", "name": "Lolita C. {"uri": "8154126226", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "22:38:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T22:38:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T22:37:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.centralmaine.com/2024/05/30/u-s-britain-strike-houthi-rebel-targets-in-yemen-after-surge-in-shipping-attacks/", "title": "U.S., Britain strike Houthi rebel targets in Yemen after surge in shipping attacks", "body": "This undated photo shows the Laax, a Greek-owned, Marshall Islands-flagged ship that came under attack by Yemen's Houthi rebels earlier this week. The U.S. and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group. Etat Major des Armees via Associated Press\n\nWASHINGTON -- The U.S. and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, three U.S. officials said.\n\nAccording to the officials, American and British fighter jets and U.S. ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the U.S. were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that the military had determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe strikes come a day after a U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen. The Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It marked the third such downing this month alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. While no group claimed responsibility, suspicion fell on the Houthis.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the U.S. and U.K. militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12. But the U.S. also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other U.S. warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, including the seizure of one vessel and the sinking of another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nU.S. warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the U.S. won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. But the counterattacks haven't appeared to diminish the Houthis' campaign against shipping in the region.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nComments are not available on this story.\n\nSend questions/comments {"uri": "8155153077", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "12:57:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T12:57:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T12:55:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://thefrontierpost.com/yemens-houthis-respond-to-us-uk-attack-with-strike-on-us-aircraft-carrier-eisenhower-in-red-sea/", "title": "Yemen's Houthis respond to US-UK attack with strike on US aircraft carrier Eisenhower in Red Sea", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP): Yemen's Houthis launched a retaliatory missile attack on the US aircraft carrier Eisenhower in the Red Sea in response to US-UK strikes on the Yemeni provinces of Sanaa, Hodeidah and Taiz that killed 16 people, Houthi military spokesperson Yahya Saree said in a televised statement on Friday.\n\nThe Houthi's Al-Masirah television said on Friday the attack wounded at least 42 people.\n\nThe strikes targeted a radio building in Hodeidah's Al-Hawk district and port of Salif.\n\nThe US and Britain struck 13 Houthi targets in several locations in Yemen on Thursday in response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, three US officials said.\n\nYemen's Houthis launched a missile attack on the US aircraft carrier Eisenhower in the Red Sea in response to US-UK strikes on the Yemeni provinces of Sanaa, Hodeidah and Taiz, Houthi military spokesperson Yahya Saree said in a televised statement on Friday.\n\nAccording to the officials, American and British fighter jets and US ships hit a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the US were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe strikes come a day after a US MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It marked the third such downing this month alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. While no group claimed responsibility, suspicion fell on the Houthis.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the US and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12. But the US also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe US F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other US warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the US Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nUS warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the US won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity to provide early details of an ongoing military operation.\n\nAlso struck by the U.S. were eight uncrewed aerial vehicles in Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen that were determined to be presenting a threat to American and coalition forces.\n\nThe strikes come a day after a U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone went down in Yemen, and the Houthis released footage they said showed the aircraft being targeted with a surface-to-air missile in a desert region of Yemen's central Marib province. It marked the third such downing this month alone.\n\nAlso earlier this week, missile attacks twice damaged a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-owned ship in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, with a private security firm saying radio traffic suggested the vessel took on water after being struck. While no group claimed responsibility, suspicion fell on the Houthis.\n\nThis is the fifth time that the U.S. and British militaries have conducted a combined operation against the Houthis since Jan. 12. But the U.S. also has been carrying out almost daily strikes to take out Houthi targets, including incoming missiles and drones aimed at ships, as well as weapons that were prepared to launch.\n\nThe U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets launched from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other U.S. warships in the region also participated.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking some 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration.\n\nShipping through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden has declined because of the threat.\n\nU.S. warships, meanwhile, took out a number of missile launchers and drones targeting vessels in the region over the past week.\n\nPresident Joe Biden and other senior leaders have repeatedly warned that the U.S. won't tolerate the Houthi attacks against commercial shipping. But the counterattacks haven't appeared to diminish the Houthis' campaign against shipping in the region.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9604794", "eventUri": "eng-9604794", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-01-12", "textStart": 1684, "textEnd": 1691}, {"amb": false,
