{"uri": "2024-05-373123305", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "10:06:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T10:06:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T09:46:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.wboc.com/news/international/ship-attacked-by-yemens-houthi-rebels-was-full-of-grain-bound-for-iran-the-groups/article_a505413c-7d6a-53ad-88cc-cc3748ed7feb.html", "title": "Ship attacked by Yemen's Houthi rebels was full of grain bound for Iran, the group's main benefactor", "body": "A Greek-owned and Marshall Islands-flagged bulk carrier that came under attack by Yemen's Houthi rebels earlier this week had a cargo of grain bound for Iran\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- A Greek-owned, Marshall Islands-flagged bulk carrier that came under attack by Yemen's Houthi rebels earlier this week had a cargo of grain bound for Iran, the group's main benefactor, authorities said Thursday.\n\nThe attack on the Laax comes as the Houthis continue their attacks on shipping throughout the Red Sea corridor, part of a campaign they say aims at pressuring Israel and the West over the war in Gaza. However, as shipping through that artery has dropped during the months of attacks, the rebels have struck vessels associated with Iran, as well as Tehran's economic lifelines of China and Russia.\n\nInitially after the attack, the Laax had listed its destination as Fujairah in the United Arab Emirates. On Thursday, however, its listed destination instead appeared to be Bandar Khomeini, Iran.\n\nA statement released by French naval forces based in the UAE that patrol the Middle East also identified the vessel's grain shipment as being bound for Iran. It said that a team from Djibouti had inspected the damage caused by the attack, which it said involved both drones and missiles, and found no remaining dangerous explosives onboard the ship.\n\nImages released by the French navy showed damage both at the waterline of the vessel, as well as on its deck.\n\nTuesday's attack saw five missiles hit the Laax during the hourslong assault, the private security firm LSS-SAPU told The Associated Press. LSS-SAPU, which earlier helped evacuate mariners from the Houthi-attacked Rubymar that later sunk, said there had been no prior warning by radio from the Houthis.\n\nLSS-SAPU had three armed security guards onboard the Laax at the time of the attack. Among the ship's crew were 13 Filipinos and one Ukrainian, the Philippine Department of Migrant Workers said in a statement.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians there. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking around 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, killed three sailors, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration.\n\nOn Wednesday, another U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone apparently crashed in Yemen, with the Houthis claiming they fired a surface-to-air missile at it. The U.S. Air Force didn't report any aircraft missing, leading to suspicion that the drone may have been piloted by the CIA. {"uri": "8152317043", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-29", "time": "21:11:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-29T21:11:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-29T21:11:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2954734-houthi-attacks-disrupt-global-shipping-amid-rising-tensions", "title": "Houthi Attacks Disrupt Global Shipping Amid Rising Tensions | Law-Order", "body": "Yemen's Houthi group launched coordinated attacks on six ships across three seas, damaging the Marshall Islands-flagged Laax. While some ships like the Maersk Hartford were unaffected, the attacks created significant disruption. The Houthis, targeting vessels linked to Israel and its allies, have intensified their campaign since November, complicating global shipping routes.\n\nYemen's Houthis launched attacks on six ships in three different seas, the Iran-backed group said on Wednesday, including the Marshall Islands-flagged bulk carrier Laax that was damaged after reporting a missile strike off the Yemeni coast. Security and shipping sources confirmed the Houthis hit the Laax in a barrage of attacks on Tuesday. In a televised speech, the group also said it targeted the Morea and Sealady in the Red Sea, the Alba and Maersk Hartford in the Arabian Sea and the Minerva Antonia in the Mediterranean.\n\nThe U.S.-flagged Maersk Hartford container ship was not the subject of a drone or missile attack, said Ed Hanley, chief operating officer of U.S.-based Maersk Line, which owns the vessel. \"I can't speak to the other five ships, but the Hartford is fine,\" Hanley said in a telephone interview. \"Nothing happened.\" Reuters was not immediately able to reach the registered owners of the other vessels for comment.\n\nThe Houthis, who describe their attacks as acts of solidarity with Palestinians in Israel's war in Gaza, have launched repeated drone and missile strikes in the Red Sea region since November. They have since expanded attacks to other busy waterways. Tuesday's Houthi attacks came as Israeli tanks moved into the heart of Rafah for the first time - despite an order from the International Court of Justice to end its attacks on the city, where many Palestinians had taken refuge from bombardment elsewhere.\n\nFive missiles fired from Yemen struck the Laax, which was carrying grain, but the vessel was still able to sail to its destination and the crew were safe, the ship's security company, LSS-SAPU, told Reuters on Wednesday. \"The vessel has sustained damage, she is not taking water, she is not tilting and there are no wounded onboard,\" a LSS-SAPU spokesperson said.\n\n\"She is proceeding to her destination with a normal speed.\" The spokesperson with LSS-SAPU, which was responsible for evacuating the crew from the Rubymar ship which sank after being hit by a Houthi missile earlier this year, said Laax's Greece-based owner had no connection with Israel or the United States.\n\nThe vessel last reported its position on May 28 with a destination of Bandar Imam Khomeini in Iran, LSEG shipping data showed. The Houthis have promised to attack any ships sailing toward Israeli ports, even in the Mediterranean. They also have identified U.S. and UK-affiliated vessels as targets.\n\nThe Houthi campaign has sunk one ship, the Rubymar, and included the seizure of another vessel and the killing of three crew members in yet another attack. It has disrupted global shipping by forcing vessels to avoid the nearby Suez Canal and reroute trade around Africa.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from {"uri": "2024-05-373490456", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "15:35:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T15:35:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T09:46:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/ship-attacked-yemens-houthi-rebels-094622819.html", "title": "Ship attacked by Yemen's Houthi rebels was full of grain bound for Iran, the group's main benefactor", "body": "DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- A Greek-owned, Marshall Islands-flagged bulk carrier that came under attack by Yemen's Houthi rebels earlier this week had a cargo of grain bound for Iran, the group's main benefactor, authorities said Thursday.\n\nThe attack on the Laax comes as the Houthis continue their attacks on shipping throughout the Red Sea corridor, part of a campaign they say aims at pressuring Israel and the West over the war in Gaza. However, as shipping through that artery has dropped during the months of attacks, the rebels have struck vessels associated with Iran, as well as Tehran's economic lifelines of China and Russia.\n\nInitially after the attack, the Laax had listed its destination as Fujairah in the United Arab Emirates. On Thursday, however, its listed destination instead appeared to be Bandar Khomeini, Iran.\n\nA statement released by French naval forces based in the UAE that patrol the Middle East also identified the vessel's grain shipment as being bound for Iran. It said that a team from Djibouti had inspected the damage caused by the attack, which it said involved both drones and missiles, and found no remaining dangerous explosives onboard the ship.\n\nImages released by the French navy showed damage both at the waterline of the vessel, as well as on its deck.\n\nTuesday's attack saw five missiles hit the Laax during the hourslong assault, the private security firm LSS-SAPU told The Associated Press. LSS-SAPU, which earlier helped evacuate mariners from the Houthi-attacked Rubymar that later sunk, said there had been no prior warning by radio from the Houthis.\n\nLSS-SAPU had three armed security guards onboard the Laax at the time of the attack. Among the ship's crew were 13 Filipinos and one Ukrainian, the Philippine Department of Migrant Workers said in a statement.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians there. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking around 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, killed three sailors, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration.\n\nOn Wednesday, another U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone apparently crashed in Yemen, with the Houthis claiming they fired a surface-to-air missile at it. The U.S. Air Force didn't report any aircraft missing, leading to suspicion that the drone may have been piloted by the CIA. {"uri": "2024-05-374679284", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "15:38:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T15:38:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T15:47:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.columbian.com/news/2024/may/31/houthi-rebels-say-at-least-16-killed-and-42-others-wounded-in-joint-us-british-airstrikes-in-yemen/", "title": "Houthi rebels say at least 16 killed and 42 others wounded in joint US-British airstrikes in Yemen", "body": "By JON GAMBRELL and LOLITA C. BALDOR, JON GAMBRELL and LOLITA C. BALDOR, Associated Press\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- Joint British-U.S. airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 42 others, the rebels said Friday, the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels' attacks on shipping.\n\nThree U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity to describe a then-ongoing attack, described the strikes Thursday as hitting a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. They called it a response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden over the Israel-Hamas war.\n\nThe U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets involved in the strikes took off from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. Other U.S. warships in the region also participated.\n\nBut the Houthis focused Friday morning on a strike they said struck a building housing Hodeida Radio and civilian homes in the port city on the Red Sea. Their Al Masirah satellite news channel aired images of one bloodied man being carried down stairs and others in the hospital, receiving aid. {"uri": "2024-05-373115443", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "09:59:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T09:59:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T05:46:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/business/articles/2024-05-30/ship-attacked-by-yemens-houthi-rebels-was-full-of-grain-bound-for-iran-the-groups-main-benefactor", "title": "Ship Attacked by Yemen's Houthi Rebels Was Full of Grain Bound for Iran, the Group's Main Benefactor", "body": "DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- A Greek-owned, Marshall Islands-flagged bulk carrier that came under attack by Yemen's Houthi rebels earlier this week had a cargo of grain bound for Iran, the group's main benefactor, authorities said Thursday.\n\nThe attack on the Laax comes as the Houthis continue their attacks on shipping throughout the Red Sea corridor, part of a campaign they say aims at pressuring Israel and the West over the war in Gaza. However, as shipping through that artery has dropped during the months of attacks, the rebels have struck vessels associated with Iran, as well as Tehran's economic lifelines of China and Russia.\n\nInitially after the attack, the Laax had listed its destination as Fujairah in the United Arab Emirates. On Thursday, however, its listed destination instead appeared to be Bandar Khomeini, Iran.\n\nA statement released by French naval forces based in the UAE that patrol the Middle East also identified the vessel's grain shipment as being bound for Iran. It said that a team from Djibouti had inspected the damage caused by the attack, which it said involved both drones and missiles, and found no remaining dangerous explosives onboard the ship.\n\nImages released by the French navy showed damage both at the waterline of the vessel, as well as on its deck.\n\nTuesday's attack saw five missiles hit the Laax during the hourslong assault, the private security firm LSS-SAPU told The Associated Press. LSS-SAPU, which earlier helped evacuate mariners from the Houthi-attacked Rubymar that later sunk, said there had been no prior warning by radio from the Houthis.\n\nLSS-SAPU had three armed security guards onboard the Laax at the time of the attack. Among the ship's crew were 13 Filipinos and one Ukrainian, the Philippine Department of Migrant Workers said in a statement.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians there. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking around 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, killed three sailors, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration.\n\nOn Wednesday, another U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone apparently crashed in Yemen, with the Houthis claiming they fired a surface-to-air missile at it. The U.S. Air Force didn't report any aircraft missing, leading to suspicion that the drone may have been piloted by the CIA. As many as three may have been lost this month alone.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8152310436", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-29", "time": "21:05:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-29T21:05:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-29T21:04:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/yemens-houthis-launch-attacks-at-six-ships-in-three-seas-20240529", "title": "Yemen's Houthis launch attacks at six ships in three seas | News24", "body": "The Iran-backed group says its attacks on shipping are in solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza.\n\nYemen's Houthis launched attacks on six ships in three different seas, the Iran-backed group said on Wednesday, including the Marshall Islands-flagged bulk carrier Laax that was damaged after reporting a missile strike off the Yemeni coast.\n\nThe Houthis attacked Laax in a barrage of attacks on Tuesday. They also targeted the Morea and Sealady in the Red Sea, the Alba and Maersk Hartford in the Arabian Sea and the Minerva Antonia in the Mediterranean, Houthi military spokesperson Yahya Saree said in a televised speech.\n\nThe Houthis, who describe their attacks as acts of solidarity with Palestinians in Israel's war in Gaza, have launched repeated drone and missile strikes in the Red Sea region since November. They have since expanded attacks to other busy waterways.\n\nTuesday's Houthi attacks came as Israeli tanks moved into the heart of Rafah for the first time - despite an order from the International Court of Justice to end its attacks on the city, where many Palestinians had taken refuge from bombardment elsewhere.\n\nFive missiles fired from Yemen struck the Laax, which was carrying grain, but the vessel was still able to sail to its destination and the crew were safe, the ship's security company, LSS-SAPU, told Reuters on Wednesday.\n\n\"The vessel has sustained damage, she is not taking water, she is not tilting and there are no wounded onboard,\" a LSS-SAPU spokesperson said.\n\n\"She is proceeding to her destination with a normal speed.\"\n\nThe spokesperson with LSS-SAPU, which was responsible for evacuating the crew from the Rubymar ship which sank after being hit by a Houthi missile earlier this year, said Laax's Greece-based owner had no connection with Israel or the United States.\n\nThe vessel last reported its position on 28 May with a destination of Bandar Imam Khomeini in Iran, LSEG shipping data showed.\n\nThe Houthis have promised to attack any ships sailing towards Israeli ports, even in the Mediterranean. They also have identified US and UK-affiliated vessels as targets.\n\nThe US-flagged Maersk Hartford container ship appears to be the only vessel among the recently attacked with ties to nations the Houthis say they target, according to LSEG data. The Morea coal bulker and Sealady wheat carrier are Malta-flagged, the Minerva Antonia chemical tanker is Greek-flagged and the Alba coal carrier flies the flag of Portugal.\n\nRegistered owners for those vessels in LSEG's database are linked to addresses in the United States, Singapore, Malta, Germany and Greece, respectively. Reuters was not immediately able to reach those vessels' registered owners for comment.\n\nThe Houthi campaign has sunk one ship, the Rubymar, and involved the seizure of another vessel, killed two Two children and four women were among the dead.\n\nPalestinians in the border city of Rafah have reported heavy fighting in recent days as Israel's military widened its offensive in the south, seizing control of the entire length of Gaza's border with Egypt. Fighting in Rafah has spurred more than 1 million Palestinians to flee, most of whom had already been displaced earlier in the war. They now seek refuge in makeshift tent camps and other war-ravaged areas, where they lack shelter, food, water and other essentials for survival, the United Nations says.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nJoint British-United States airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others, the rebels said Friday. That's the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels' attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza.\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to the Health Ministry, which doesn't distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nIsrael launched its war in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack in which militants stormed into southern Israel, killed some 1,200 people -- mostly civilians -- and abducted about 250. Israel says around 100 hostages are still captive in Gaza, along with the bodies of around 30 more.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Houthi rebels say at least 16 killed and 35 others wounded in joint U.S.-British airstrikes in Yemen.\n\n-- Slovenia's government endorses recognition of a Palestinian state.\n\n-- A pro-Palestinian camp at Wayne State is dismantled while MIT students walk out of commencement.\n\n-- A global aid group asks warring forces to respect its neutrality, saying 24 of its aid workers have been killed.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of the war in Gaza at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nAIRSTRIKES IN CENTRAL GAZA KILL AT LEAST A DOZEN PEOPLE\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH -- At least a dozen people were killed, including children, in two airstrikes Friday in Central Gaza, according to hospital officials and Associated Press journalists who counted the bodies.\n\nThe strikes hit Nuseirat and Bureij, two children and four women were among those killed and the bodies were brought to the Al Aqsa Hospital in Deir al-Balah.\n\nA funeral for all 12 people was held Friday.\n\nIsrael's campaign of bombardment and offensives in Gaza has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians and wounded more than 80,000, according to the Gaza Health Ministry. Its count does not differentiate between civilians and combatants.\n\nAIRSTRIKES TARGETING YEMEN'S HOUTHI REBELS KILL AT LEAST 16\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates -- Joint British-United States airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others, the rebels said Friday -- the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels' attacks on shipping.\n\nThe Houthis have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians there. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking around 250 hostage.\n\nHouthis said Friday morning that one of the strikes struck a building housing Hodeida Radio and civilian homes in the port city on the Red Sea. Their Al Masirah satellite news channel aired images of one bloodied man being carried downstairs and others receiving aid in the hospital. The Houthis described all those killed and hurt in Hodeida as civilians, something The Associated Press could not immediately confirm. The rebel force that's held Yemen's capital, Sanaa, since 2014 includes fighters who often are not in uniform.\n\nOther strikes hit outside of Sanaa near its airport and communication equipment in Taiz, the broadcaster said. Little other information was released on those sites -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\nThe U.S. and the U.K. have launched strikes against the Houthis since January. Abdul Malik al-Houthi, the Houthis' secretive supreme leader, offered an overall death toll for the strikes up to that point as 40 people killed and 35 others wounded. He did not offer a breakdown between civilian and combatant casualties at the time.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, killed three sailors, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration. {"uri": "8155128352", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "12:41:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T12:41:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T12:39:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.northernirelandnews.com/news/274391176/houthis-claim-missile-strike-on-us-aircraft-carrier", "title": "Houthis claim missile strike on US aircraft carrier", "body": "According to the group's spokesman, the attack came in response to Anglo-American assaults on Yemen\n\nYemen's Houthis on Friday launched a missile attack on the US aircraft carrier Dwight D. Eisenhower in the Red Sea, according to a statement made on X (former Twitter) by the group's spokesman Yahya Saree.\n\nSaree claimed the attack came in response to US and UK strikes on the Yemeni provinces of Sanaa, Hodeidah and Taiz. The strikes allegedly targeted civilian infrastructure and resulted in the deaths of 16 people and over 40 wounded.\n\nSeveral missiles allegedly struck a Hodeidah radio station building, as well as the area surrounding Al-Thawra Hospital and a Coast Guard headquarters in Port Al-Salib, where several commercial ships were damaged. \"This represents a clear targeting of civilian objects, a blatant violation of all international laws, and a full-fledged war crime. Therefore, in response to these crimes and the American-British aggression... the Yemeni armed forces carried out a joint military operation targeting the American aircraft carrier Eisenhower in the Red Sea,\" Saree said in his statement.\n\nHe claimed that the strike on the US aircraft carrier \"was accurate and direct,\" but did not give details on damage the vessel suffered.\n\nThe US Navy has not yet issued any statements regarding the purported attack on its ship.\n\nOn Thursday, British and American forces launched a large-scale attack on alleged Houthi targets in Yemen as part of an ongoing operation to halt the group's strikes on commercial ships traversing the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden. According to media reports citing military officials, the coalition attacks hit multiple Houthi underground facilities, missile launchers, and command and control sites, as well as a Houthi ship and aerial vehicles in areas of Yemen said to be controlled by the militants.\n\nThe Houthis, a Shia Islamist group that controls a large part of Yemen, have been attacking merchant vessels since October, calling it an act of solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza. {"uri": "8154883957", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "10:03:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T10:03:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T10:03:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://wtop.com/national/2024/05/the-latest-12-killed-in-airstrikes-in-central-gaza-as-strikes-targeting-houthi-rebels-kill-16/", "title": "The Latest | 12 killed in airstrikes in Central Gaza as strikes targeting Houthi rebels kill 16 - WTOP News", "body": "At least a dozen people were killed in two airstrikes Friday in Central Gaza. Two children and four women were...\n\nAt least a dozen people were killed in two airstrikes Friday in Central Gaza. Two children and four women were among the dead.\n\nPalestinians in the border city of Rafah have reported heavy fighting in recent days as Israel's military widened its offensive in the south, seizing control of the entire length of Gaza's border with Egypt. Fighting in Rafah has spurred more than 1 million Palestinians to flee, most of whom had already been displaced earlier in the war. They now seek refuge in makeshift tent camps and other war-ravaged areas, where they lack shelter, food, water and other essentials for survival, the United Nations says.\n\nJoint British-United States airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others, the rebels said Friday. That's the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels' attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza.\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to the Health Ministry, which doesn't distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nIsrael launched its war in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack in which militants stormed into southern Israel, killed some 1,200 people -- mostly civilians -- and abducted about 250. Israel says around 100 hostages are still captive in Gaza, along with the bodies of around 30 more.\n\n-- A global aid group asks warring forces to respect its neutrality, saying 24 of its aid workers have been killed.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of the war in Gaza at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH -- At least a dozen people were killed, including children, in two airstrikes Friday in Central Gaza, according to hospital officials and Associated Press journalists who counted the bodies.\n\nThe strikes hit Nuseirat and Bureij, two children and four women were among those killed and the bodies were brought to the Al Aqsa Hospital in Deir al-Balah.\n\nA funeral for all 12 people was held Friday.\n\nIsrael's campaign of bombardment and offensives in Gaza has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians and wounded more than 80,000, according to the Gaza Health Ministry. Its count does not differentiate between civilians and combatants.\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates -- Joint British-United States airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others, the rebels said Friday -- the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels' attacks on shipping.\n\nThe Houthis have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians there. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking around 250 hostage.\n\nHouthis said Friday morning that one of the strikes struck a building housing Hodeida Radio and civilian homes in the port city on the Red Sea. Their Al Masirah satellite news channel aired images of one bloodied man being carried downstairs and others receiving aid in the hospital. The Houthis described all those killed and hurt in Hodeida as civilians, something The Associated Press could not immediately confirm. The rebel force that's held Yemen's capital, Sanaa, since 2014 includes fighters who often are not in uniform.\n\nOther strikes hit outside of Sanaa near its airport and communication equipment in Taiz, the broadcaster said. Little other information was released on those sites -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\nThe U.S. and the U.K. have launched strikes against the Houthis since January. Abdul Malik al-Houthi, the Houthis' secretive supreme leader, offered an overall death toll for the strikes up to that point as 40 people killed and 35 others wounded. He did not offer a breakdown between civilian and combatant casualties at the time.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, killed three sailors, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration. This week, they attacked a ship carrying grain to Iran, the rebels' main benefactor.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. They also targeted the Morea and Sealady in the Red Sea, the Alba and Maersk Hartford in the Arabian Sea and the Minerva Antonia in the Mediterranean, Houthi military spokesperson Yahya Saree said in a televised speech.\n\nThe Houthis, who describe their attacks as acts of solidarity with Palestinians in Israel's war in Gaza, have launched repeated drone and missile strikes in the Red Sea region since November. They have since expanded attacks to other busy waterways.\n\nTuesday's Houthi attacks came as Israeli tanks moved into the heart of Rafah for the first time - despite an order from the International Court of Justice to end its attacks on the city, where many Palestinians had taken refuge from bombardment elsewhere.\n\nFive missiles fired from Yemen struck the Laax, which was carrying grain, but the vessel was still able to sail to its destination and the crew were safe, the ship's security company, LSS-SAPU, told Reuters on Wednesday.\n\n\"The vessel has sustained damage, she is not taking water, she is not tilting and there are no wounded onboard,\" a LSS-SAPU spokesperson said.\n\n\"She is proceeding to her destination with a normal speed.\"\n\nThe spokesperson with LSS-SAPU, which was responsible for evacuating the crew from the Rubymar ship which sank after being hit by a Houthi missile earlier this year, said Laax's Greece-based owner had no connection with Israel or the United States.\n\nThe vessel last reported its position on May 28 with a destination of Bandar Imam Khomeini in Iran, LSEG shipping data showed.\n\nThe Houthis have promised to attack any ships sailing towards Israeli ports, even in the Mediterranean. They also have identified U.S. and UK-affiliated vessels as targets.\n\nThe U.S.-flagged Maersk Hartford container ship appears to be the only vessel among the recently attacked with ties to nations the Houthis say they target, according to LSEG data. The Morea coal bulker and Sealady wheat carrier are Malta-flagged, the Minerva Antonia chemical tanker is Greek-flagged and the Alba coal carrier flies the flag of Portugal.\n\nRegistered owners for those vessels in LSEG's database are linked to addresses in the United States, Singapore, Malta, Germany and Greece, respectively. {"uri": "8152379924", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-29", "time": "22:21:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-29T22:21:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-29T22:20:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.marinelink.com/news/houthis-claim-attack-six-ships-three-seas-514083", "title": "Houthis Claim to Attack Six Ships in Three Seas", "body": "Yemen's Houthis launched attacks on six ships in three different seas, the Iran-backed group said on Wednesday, including the Marshall Islands-flagged bulk carrier Laax that was damaged after reporting a missile strike off the Yemeni coast.\n\nSecurity and shipping sources confirmed the Houthis hit the Laax in a barrage of attacks on Tuesday. In a televised speech, the group also said it targeted the Morea and Sealady in the Red Sea, the Alba and Maersk Hartford in the Arabian Sea and the Minerva Antonia in the Mediterranean.\n\nThe U.S.-flagged Maersk Hartford container ship was not the subject of a drone or missile attack, said Ed Hanley, chief operating officer of U.S.-based Maersk Line, which owns the vessel.\n\n\"I can't speak to the other five ships, but the Hartford is fine,\" Hanley said in a telephone interview. \"Nothing happened.\"\n\nReuters was not immediately able to reach the registered owners of the other vessels for comment.\n\nThe Houthis, who describe their attacks as acts of solidarity with Palestinians in Israel's war in Gaza, have launched repeated drone and missile strikes in the Red Sea region since November. They have since expanded attacks to other busy waterways.\n\nTuesday's Houthi attacks came as Israeli tanks moved into the heart of Rafah for the first time - despite an order from the International Court of Justice to end its attacks on the city, where many Palestinians had taken refuge from bombardment elsewhere.\n\nFive missiles fired from Yemen struck the Laax, which was carrying grain, but the vessel was still able to sail to its destination and the crew were safe, the ship's security company, LSS-SAPU, told Reuters on Wednesday.\n\n\"The vessel has sustained damage, she is not taking water, she is not tilting and there are no wounded onboard,\" a LSS-SAPU spokesperson said.\n\n\"She is proceeding to her destination with a normal speed.\"\n\nThe spokesperson with LSS-SAPU, which was responsible for evacuating the crew from the Rubymar ship which sank after being hit by a Houthi missile earlier this year, said Laax's Greece-based owner had no connection with Israel or the United States.\n\nThe vessel last reported its position on May 28 with a destination of Bandar Imam Khomeini in Iran, LSEG shipping data showed.\n\nThe Houthis have promised to attack any ships sailing toward Israeli ports, even in the Mediterranean. They also have identified U.S. and UK-affiliated vessels as targets.\n\nThe Houthi campaign has sunk one ship, the Rubymar, and included the seizure of another vessel and the killing of three crew members in yet another attack. It has disrupted global shipping by forcing vessels to avoid the nearby Suez Canal and reroute trade around Africa.", "source": {"uri": "marinelink.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MarineLink"}, {"uri": "8153168641", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "10:21:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T10:21:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T10:20:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.arabnews.com/node/2519886/middle-east", "title": "Ship attacked by Yemen's Houthi rebels was full of grain bound for", "body": "DUBAI, United Arab Emirates: A Greek-owned, Marshall Islands-flagged bulk carrier that came under attack by Yemen's Houthi militia earlier this week had a cargo of grain bound for Iran, the group's main benefactor, authorities said Thursday.\n\nThe attack on the Laax comes as the Houthis continue their attacks on shipping throughout the Red Sea corridor, part of a campaign they say aims at pressuring Israel and the West over the war in Gaza. However, as shipping through that artery has dropped during the months of attacks, the militia have struck vessels associated with Iran, as well as Tehran's economic lifelines of China and Russia.\n\nInitially after the attack, the Laax had listed its destination as Fujairah in the United Arab Emirates. On Thursday, however, its listed destination instead appeared to be Bandar Khomeini, Iran.\n\nA statement released by French naval forces based in the UAE that patrol the Middle East also identified the vessel's grain shipment as being bound for Iran. It said that a team from Djibouti had inspected the damage caused by the attack, which it said involved both drones and missiles, and found no remaining dangerous explosives onboard the ship.\n\nImages released by the French navy showed damage both at the waterline of the vessel, as well as on its deck.\n\nTuesday's attack saw five missiles hit the Laax during the hourslong assault, the private security firm LSS-SAPU told The Associated Press. LSS-SAPU, which earlier helped evacuate mariners from the Houthi-attacked Rubymar that later sunk, said there had been no prior warning by radio from the Houthis.\n\nLSS-SAPU had three armed security guards onboard the Laax at the time of the attack. Among the ship's crew were 13 Filipinos and one Ukrainian, the Philippine Department of Migrant Workers said in a statement.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians there. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking around 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, killed three sailors, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the US Maritime Administration.\n\nOn Wednesday, another US MQ-9 Reaper drone apparently crashed in Yemen, with the Houthis claiming they fired a surface-to-air missile at it. The US Air Force didn't report any aircraft missing, leading to suspicion that the drone may have been piloted by the CIA. {"uri": "8153283139", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "11:32:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T11:32:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T11:31:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://kayhanlife.com/news/middle-east/islamic-republic-backed-houthis-claim-to-attack-six-ships-in-three-seas/", "title": "Islamic Republic-Backed Houthis Claim to Attack Six Ships in Three Seas - KAYHAN LIFE", "body": "By Nayera Abdallah, Clauda Tanios and Jonathan Saul\n\nDUBAI/LONDON, May 29 (Reuters) - Yemen's Houthis launched attacks on six ships in three different seas, the Iran-backed group said on Wednesday, including the Marshall Islands-flagged bulk carrier Laax that was damaged after reporting a missile strike off the Yemeni coast.\n\nSecurity and shipping sources confirmed the Houthis hit the Laax in a barrage of attacks on Tuesday. In a televised speech, the group also said it targeted the Morea and Sealady in the Red Sea, the Alba and Maersk Hartford in the Arabian Sea and the Minerva Antonia in the Mediterranean.\n\nThe U.S.-flagged Maersk Hartford container ship was not the subject of a drone or missile attack, said Ed Hanley, chief operating officer of U.S.-based Maersk Line, which owns the vessel.\n\n\"I can't speak to the other five ships, but the Hartford is fine,\" Hanley said in a telephone interview. \"Nothing happened.\"\n\nIslamic Republic Made Sea-Launched Ballistic Missile Available to Houthis, Tasnim Newspaper Says\n\nReuters was not immediately able to reach the registered owners of the other vessels for comment.\n\nThe Houthis, who describe their attacks as acts of solidarity with Palestinians in Israel's war in Gaza, have launched repeated drone and missile strikes in the Red Sea region since November. They have since expanded attacks to other busy waterways.\n\nTuesday's Houthi attacks came as Israeli tanks moved into the heart of Rafah for the first time - despite an order from the International Court of Justice to end its attacks on the city, where many Palestinians had taken refuge from bombardment elsewhere.\n\nFive missiles fired from Yemen struck the Laax, which was carrying grain, but the vessel was still able to sail to its destination and the crew were safe, the ship's security company, LSS-SAPU, told Reuters on Wednesday.\n\n\"The vessel has sustained damage, she is not taking water, she is not tilting and there are no wounded onboard,\" a LSS-SAPU spokesperson said.\n\n\"She is proceeding to her destination with a normal speed.\"\n\nThe spokesperson with LSS-SAPU, which was responsible for evacuating the crew from the Rubymar ship which sank after being hit by a Houthi missile earlier this year, said Laax's Greece-based owner had no connection with Israel or the United States.\n\nThe vessel last reported its position on May 28 with a destination of Bandar Imam Khomeini in Iran, LSEG shipping data showed.\n\nThe Houthis have promised to attack any ships sailing toward Israeli ports, even in the Mediterranean. They also have identified U.S. and UK-affiliated vessels as targets.\n\nThe Houthi campaign has sunk one ship, the Rubymar, and included the seizure of another vessel and the killing of three crew members in yet another attack. It has disrupted global shipping by forcing vessels to avoid the nearby Suez Canal and reroute trade around Africa.", "source": {"uri": "kayhanlife.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KAYHAN LIFE"}, They marked the fifth round of coalition strikes against the Houthis, who have repeatedly attacked US Navy ships and commercial vessels in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden. The two waterways, separated by the Bab-el-Mandeb strait, are critical to international shipping routes.\n\nThe last round of strikes occurred on February 24, as the US and UK targeted Houthi weapons and radar sites.\n\nThe US has tried to disrupt the Houthi's ability to target commercial vessels and US warships by going after their primary weapons, including anti-ship cruise missiles, ballistic missiles and one-way attack drones. The US has also destroyed maritime drones and underwater drones. The resumption of strikes follows an uptick in Houthi attacks over the last week.\n\nThis week, the US destroyed Houthi missile launchers in Yemen and intercepted aerial attack drones.\n\nOn Tuesday, three Houthi anti-ship ballistic missiles struck a Greek-owned and operated merchant ship in the Red Sea, according to US Central Command. There were no injuries, according to Central Command, and the M/V Lax was able to continue its voyage.\n\nThe US spearheaded Operation Prosperity Guardian in December to protect international shipping, banding together with other nations to intercept Houthi attacks. The aircraft carrier USS Dwight D. Eisenhower and a number of destroyers have patrolled the waters of the region to intercept Houthi launches.\n\nThe USS Carney, a guided missile destroyer that recently returned from the Middle East, {"uri": "2024-05-374308831", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "10:04:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T10:04:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T09:48:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/national-and-world-news/israel-conflict/the-latest-12-killed-in-airstrikes-in-central-gaza-as-strikes-targeting-houthi-rebels-kill/article_3d835bd3-61c2-5efd-a3ad-2a6a512b840e.html", "title": "The Latest | 12 killed in airstrikes in Central Gaza as strikes targeting Houthi rebels kill 16", "body": "At least a dozen people have been killed in two airstrikes in Central Gaza\n\nAt least a dozen people were killed in two airstrikes Friday in Central Gaza. Two children and four women were among the dead.\n\nPalestinians in the border city of Rafah have reported heavy fighting in recent days as Israel's military widened its offensive in the south, seizing control of the entire length of Gaza's border with Egypt. Fighting in Rafah has spurred more than 1 million Palestinians to flee, most of whom had already been displaced earlier in the war. They now seek refuge in makeshift tent camps and other war-ravaged areas, where they lack shelter, food, water and other essentials for survival, the United Nations says.\n\nJoint British-United States airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others, the rebels said Friday. That's the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels' attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza.\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to the Health Ministry, which doesn't distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nIsrael launched its war in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack in which militants stormed into southern Israel, killed some 1,200 people -- mostly civilians -- and abducted about 250. Israel says around 100 hostages are still captive in Gaza, along with the bodies of around 30 more.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Houthi rebels say at least 16 killed and 35 others wounded in joint U.S.-British airstrikes in Yemen.\n\n-- Slovenia's government endorses recognition of a Palestinian state.\n\n-- A pro-Palestinian camp at Wayne State is dismantled while MIT students walk out of commencement.\n\n-- A global aid group asks warring forces to respect its neutrality, saying 24 of its aid workers have been killed.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of the war in Gaza at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nAIRSTRIKES IN CENTRAL GAZA KILL AT LEAST A DOZEN PEOPLE\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH -- At least a dozen people were killed, including children, in two airstrikes Friday in Central Gaza, according to hospital officials and Associated Press journalists who counted the bodies.\n\nThe strikes hit Nuseirat and Bureij, two children and four women were among those killed and the bodies were brought to the Al Aqsa Hospital in Deir al-Balah.\n\nA funeral for all 12 people was held Friday.\n\nIsrael's campaign of bombardment and offensives in Gaza has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians and wounded more than 80,000, according to the Gaza Health Ministry. Its count does not differentiate between civilians and combatants.\n\nAIRSTRIKES TARGETING YEMEN'S HOUTHI REBELS KILL AT LEAST 16\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates -- Joint British-United States airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others, the rebels said Friday -- the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels' attacks on shipping.\n\nThe Houthis have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians there. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking around 250 hostage.\n\nHouthis said Friday morning that one of the strikes struck a building housing Hodeida Radio and civilian homes in the port city on the Red Sea. Their Al Masirah satellite news channel aired images of one bloodied man being carried downstairs and others receiving aid in the hospital. The Houthis described all those killed and hurt in Hodeida as civilians, something The Associated Press could not immediately confirm. The rebel force that's held Yemen's capital, Sanaa, since 2014 includes fighters who often are not in uniform.\n\nOther strikes hit outside of Sanaa near its airport and communication equipment in Taiz, the broadcaster said. Little other information was released on those sites -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\nThe U.S. and the U.K. have launched strikes against the Houthis since January. Abdul Malik al-Houthi, the Houthis' secretive supreme leader, offered an overall death toll for the strikes up to that point as 40 people killed and 35 others wounded. He did not offer a breakdown between civilian and combatant casualties at the time.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, killed three sailors, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration. This week, they attacked a ship carrying grain to Iran, the rebels' main benefactor.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. {"uri": "8155020166", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "11:29:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T11:29:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T11:28:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.democraticunderground.com/113342585", "title": "Houthi rebels say at least 16 killed and 42 others wounded in joint US-British airstrikes in Yemen", "body": "Houthi rebels say at least 16 killed and 42 others wounded in joint US-British airstrikes in Yemen\n\n[1:20 min. video at link]\n\nJoint British-U.S. airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others. It is the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels' attacks on shipping. Three U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity to describe a then-ongoing attack, described the strikes Thursday as hitting a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities.\n\nBY JON GAMBRELL AND LOLITA C. BALDOR\n\nUpdated 6:59 AM EDT, May 31, 2024\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- Joint British-U.S. airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 42 others, the rebels said Friday, the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels' attacks on shipping.\n\nThree U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity to describe a then-ongoing attack, described the strikes Thursday as hitting a wide range of underground facilities, missile launchers, command and control sites, a Houthi vessel and other facilities. They called it a response to a recent surge in attacks by the Iran-backed militia group on ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden over the Israel-Hamas war.\n\nThe U.S. F/A-18 fighter jets involved in the strikes took off from the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, officials said. {"uri": "8153851856", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "18:05:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T18:05:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T18:05:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/nation-and-world/ship-attacked-by-yemens-houthi-rebels-was-full-of-grain-bound-for-iran-3059494/", "title": "Ship attacked by Yemen's Houthi rebels was full of grain bound for Iran", "body": "A Greek-owned, Marshall Islands-flagged bulk carrier that came under attack by Yemen's Houthi terrorists earlier this week had a cargo of grain bound for Iran, the group's main benefactor, authorities said Thursday.\n\nThe attack on the Laax comes as the Houthis continue their attacks on shipping throughout the Red Sea corridor, part of a campaign they say aims at pressuring Israel and the West over the war in Gaza. However, as shipping through that artery has dropped during the months of attacks, the terrorists have struck vessels associated with Iran, as well as Tehran's economic lifelines of China and Russia.\n\nInitially after the attack, the Laax had listed its destination as Fujairah in the United Arab Emirates. On Thursday, however, its listed destination instead appeared to be Bandar Khomeini, Iran.\n\nA statement released by French naval forces based in the UAE that patrol the Middle East also identified the vessel's grain shipment as being bound for Iran. It said that a team from Djibouti had inspected the damage caused by the attack, which it said involved both drones and missiles, and found no remaining dangerous explosives onboard the ship.\n\nImages released by the French navy showed damage both at the waterline of the vessel, as well as on its deck.\n\nTuesday's attack saw five missiles hit the Laax during the hourslong assault, the private security firm LSS-SAPU told The Associated Press. LSS-SAPU, which earlier helped evacuate mariners from the Houthi-attacked Rubymar that later sunk, said there had been no prior warning by radio from the Houthis.\n\nLSS-SAPU had three armed security guards onboard the Laax at the time of the attack. Among the ship's crew were 13 Filipinos and one Ukrainian, the Philippine Department of Migrant Workers said in a statement.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, killed three sailors, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration.\n\nOn Wednesday, another U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone apparently crashed in Yemen, with the Houthis claiming they fired a surface-to-air missile at it. The U.S. Air Force didn't report any aircraft missing, leading to suspicion that the drone may have been piloted by the CIA. {"uri": "2024-05-374330685", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "10:21:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T10:21:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T09:48:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/the-latest-12-killed-in-airstrikes-in-central-gaza-as-strikes-targeting-houthi-rebels-kill/article_d53d636c-400e-5e0d-a95d-d2dd1c5db9dc.html", "title": "The Latest | 12 killed in airstrikes in Central Gaza as strikes targeting Houthi rebels kill 16", "body": "At least a dozen people have been killed in two airstrikes in Central Gaza\n\nAt least a dozen people were killed in two airstrikes Friday in Central Gaza. Two children and four women were among the dead.\n\nPalestinians in the border city of Rafah have reported heavy fighting in recent days as Israel's military widened its offensive in the south, seizing control of the entire length of Gaza's border with Egypt. Fighting in Rafah has spurred more than 1 million Palestinians to flee, most of whom had already been displaced earlier in the war. They now seek refuge in makeshift tent camps and other war-ravaged areas, where they lack shelter, food, water and other essentials for survival, the United Nations says.\n\nJoint British-United States airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others, the rebels said Friday. That's the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels' attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza.\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to the Health Ministry, which doesn't distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nIsrael launched its war in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack in which militants stormed into southern Israel, killed some 1,200 people -- mostly civilians -- and abducted about 250. Israel says around 100 hostages are still captive in Gaza, along with the bodies of around 30 more.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Houthi rebels say at least 16 killed and 35 others wounded in joint U.S.-British airstrikes in Yemen.\n\n-- Slovenia's government endorses recognition of a Palestinian state.\n\n-- A pro-Palestinian camp at Wayne State is dismantled while MIT students walk out of commencement.\n\n-- A global aid group asks warring forces to respect its neutrality, saying 24 of its aid workers have been killed.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of the war in Gaza at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nAIRSTRIKES IN CENTRAL GAZA KILL AT LEAST A DOZEN PEOPLE\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH -- At least a dozen people were killed, including children, in two airstrikes Friday in Central Gaza, according to hospital officials and Associated Press journalists who counted the bodies.\n\nThe strikes hit Nuseirat and Bureij, two children and four women were among those killed and the bodies were brought to the Al Aqsa Hospital in Deir al-Balah.\n\nA funeral for all 12 people was held Friday.\n\nIsrael's campaign of bombardment and offensives in Gaza has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians and wounded more than 80,000, according to the Gaza Health Ministry. Its count does not differentiate between civilians and combatants.\n\nAIRSTRIKES TARGETING YEMEN'S HOUTHI REBELS KILL AT LEAST 16\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates -- Joint British-United States airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others, the rebels said Friday -- the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels' attacks on shipping.\n\nThe Houthis have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians there. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking around 250 hostage.\n\nHouthis said Friday morning that one of the strikes struck a building housing Hodeida Radio and civilian homes in the port city on the Red Sea. Their Al Masirah satellite news channel aired images of one bloodied man being carried downstairs and others receiving aid in the hospital. The Houthis described all those killed and hurt in Hodeida as civilians, something The Associated Press could not immediately confirm. The rebel force that's held Yemen's capital, Sanaa, since 2014 includes fighters who often are not in uniform.\n\nOther strikes hit outside of Sanaa near its airport and communication equipment in Taiz, the broadcaster said. Little other information was released on those sites -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\nThe U.S. and the U.K. have launched strikes against the Houthis since January. Abdul Malik al-Houthi, the Houthis' secretive supreme leader, offered an overall death toll for the strikes up to that point as 40 people killed and 35 others wounded. He did not offer a breakdown between civilian and combatant casualties at the time.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, killed three sailors, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration. This week, they attacked a ship carrying grain to Iran, the rebels' main benefactor.\n\nMore from this section\n\nLocal West Virginia Business Owners Jessica and Martin Herbert Named to NSBA {"uri": "8153746390", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "16:40:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T16:40:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T16:39:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.ekathimerini.com/politics/foreign-policy/1240152/greek-owned-ship-attacked-by-yemens-houthi-rebels-was-full-of-grain-bound-for-iran/", "title": "Greek-owned ship attacked by Yemen's Houthi rebels was full of grain bound for Iran | eKathimerini.com", "body": "A Greek-owned, Marshall Islands-flagged bulk carrier that came under attack by Yemen's Houthi rebels earlier this week had a cargo of grain bound for Iran, the group's main benefactor, French authorities said Thursday.\n\nThe attack on the Laax comes as the Houthis continue their attacks on shipping throughout the Red Sea corridor, part of a campaign they say aims at pressuring Israel and the West over the war in Gaza. However, as shipping through that artery has dropped during the months of attacks, the rebels have struck vessels associated with Iran, as well as Tehran's economic lifelines of China and Russia.\n\nInitially after the attack, the Laax had listed its destination as Fujairah in the United Arab Emirates. On Thursday, however, its listed destination instead appeared to be Bandar Khomeini, Iran.\n\nA statement released by French naval forces based in the UAE that patrol the Middle East also identified the vessel's grain shipment as being bound for Iran. It said that a team from Djibouti had inspected the damage caused by the attack, which it said involved both drones and missiles, and found no remaining dangerous explosives onboard the ship.\n\nImages released by the French navy showed damage both at the waterline of the vessel, as well as on its deck.\n\nTuesday's attack saw five missiles hit the Laax during the hours-long assault, the private security firm LSS-SAPU told the Associated Press. LSS-SAPU, which earlier helped evacuate mariners from the Houthi-attacked Rubymar that later sunk, said there had been no prior warning by radio from the Houthis.\n\nLSS-SAPU had three armed security guards onboard the Laax at the time of the attack. Among the ship's crew were 13 Filipinos and one Ukrainian, the Philippine Department of Migrant Workers said in a statement.\n\nThe Houthis in recent months have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians there. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on October 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking around 250 hostage.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, killed three sailors, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the US Maritime Administration.\n\nOn Wednesday, another US MQ-9 Reaper drone apparently crashed in Yemen, with the Houthis claiming they fired a surface-to-air missile at it. The US Air Force didn't report any aircraft missing, leading to suspicion that the drone may have been piloted by the CIA. As many as three may have been lost this month alone. The Houthis also launched attacks against the Morea and Sealady vessels in the Red Sea, the Alba and Maersk Hartford in the Arabian Sea and the Minvera Antonia in the Mediterranean, military spokesperson Yahya Saree said in a televised speech.\n\nThe Laax, which was carrying a cargo of grain, was hit by five missiles fired from Yemen, but the vessel was still able to sail to its destination and the crew were safe, the ship's security company, LSS-SAPU, told Reuters on Wednesday.\n\n\"The vessel has sustained damage, she is not taking water, she is not tilting and there are no wounded onboard,\" a LSS-SAPU spokesperson said.\n\n\"She is proceeding to her destination with a normal speed.\"\n\nThe spokesperson with LSS-SAPU, which was responsible for evacuating the crew from Gaza, have launched repeated drone and missile strikes in the Red Sea region since November, later expanding to the Indian Ocean.\n\nThey promised to attack any ships sailing towards Israeli ports, even in the Mediterranean.\n\nThe group has managed to sink one ship, the Rubymar, seized another vessel, killed two crew members and disrupted global shipping by forcing vessels to avoid the nearby {"uri": "8154875760", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "10:02:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T10:02:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T09:58:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13479879/The-Latest--12-killed-airstrikes-Central-Gaza-strikes-targeting-Houthi-rebels-kill-16.html", "title": "The Latest | 12 killed in airstrikes in Central Gaza as strikes...", "body": "At least a dozen people were killed in two airstrikes Friday in Central Gaza. Two children and four women were among the dead.\n\nPalestinians in the border city of Rafah have reported heavy fighting in recent days as Israel\u00b4s military widened its offensive in the south, seizing control of the entire length of Gaza\u00b4s border with Egypt. Fighting in Rafah has spurred more than 1 million Palestinians to flee, most of whom had already been displaced earlier in the war. They now seek refuge in makeshift tent camps and other war-ravaged areas, where they lack shelter, food, water and other essentials for survival, the United Nations says.\n\nJoint British-United States airstrikes targeting Yemen\u00b4s Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others, the rebels said Friday. That\u00b4s the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels\u00b4 attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza.\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to the Health Ministry, which doesn\u00b4t distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nIsrael launched its war in Gaza after Hamas\u00b4 Oct. 7 attack in which militants stormed into southern Israel, killed some 1,200 people - mostly civilians - and abducted about 250. Israel says around 100 hostages are still captive in Gaza, along with the bodies of around 30 more.\n\nCurrently:\n\nSmoke rises following an Israeli airstrike in Rafah, Gaza Strip, Thursday, May 30, 2024. (AP Photo/Abdel Kareem Hana)\n\n- Houthi rebels say at least 16 killed and 35 others wounded in joint U.S.-British airstrikes in Yemen.\n\n- Slovenia\u00b4s government endorses recognition of a Palestinian state.\n\n- A pro-Palestinian camp at Wayne State is dismantled while MIT students walk out of commencement.\n\n- A global aid group asks warring forces to respect its neutrality, saying 24 of its aid workers have been killed.\n\nFollow AP\u00b4s coverage of the war in Gaza at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH - At least a dozen people were killed, including children, in two airstrikes Friday in Central Gaza, according to hospital officials and Associated Press journalists who counted the bodies.\n\nThe strikes hit Nuseirat and Bureij, two children and four women were among those killed and the bodies were brought to the Al Aqsa Hospital in Deir al-Balah.\n\nA funeral for all 12 people was held Friday.\n\nIsrael\u00b4s campaign of bombardment and offensives in Gaza has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians and wounded more than 80,000, according to the Gaza Health Ministry. Its count does not differentiate between civilians and combatants.\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates - Joint British-United States airstrikes targeting Yemen\u00b4s Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 35 others, the rebels said Friday - the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels\u00b4 attacks on shipping.\n\nThe Houthis have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians there. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking around 250 hostage.\n\nHouthis said Friday morning that one of the strikes struck a building housing Hodeida Radio and civilian homes in the port city on the Red Sea. Their Al Masirah satellite news channel aired images of one bloodied man being carried downstairs and others receiving aid in the hospital. The Houthis described all those killed and hurt in Hodeida as civilians, something The Associated Press could not immediately confirm. The rebel force that\u00b4s held Yemen\u00b4s capital, Sanaa, since 2014 includes fighters who often are not in uniform.\n\nOther strikes hit outside of Sanaa near its airport and communication equipment in Taiz, the broadcaster said. Little other information was released on those sites - likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck.\n\nThe U.S. and the U.K. have launched strikes against the Houthis since January. Abdul Malik al-Houthi, the Houthis\u00b4 secretive supreme leader, offered an overall death toll for the strikes up to that point as 40 people killed and 35 others wounded. He did not offer a breakdown between civilian and combatant casualties at the time.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, killed three sailors, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration. This week, they attacked a ship carrying grain to Iran, the rebels\u00b4 main benefactor.\n\nA Palestinian moves a wounded child in an Israeli bombardment on the Gaza Strip to Al Aqsa hospital in Deir al Balah, central Gaza Strip, late Thursday, May 30, 2024. (AP Photo/Tsafrir Abayov)\n\nA Palestinian flag flies next to a Slovenian, center, and a European Union flag, right, at the government building in Ljubljana, Slovenia, Thursday, May 30, 2024. Slovenia's government has endorsed a motion to recognize a Palestinian state and sent it to parliament for approval. Prime Minister Robert Golob's ruling liberal coalition has a comfortable majority in the 90-member assembly and the vote should be formality. The decision by the Slovenian government on Thursday comes just two days after Spain, Norway and Ireland recognized a Palestinian state. It was a move that was slammed by Israel. {"uri": "8155067272", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "12:00:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T12:00:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T12:00:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.wral.com/story/the-latest-12-killed-in-airstrikes-in-central-gaza-as-strikes-targeting-houthi-rebels-kill-16/21458872/", "title": "The Latest | 12 killed in airstrikes in central Gaza as strikes targeting Houthi rebels kill 16", "body": "At least a dozen people were killed in two airstrikes Friday in central Gaza. Two children and four women were among the dead.\n\nAt least a dozen people were killed in two airstrikes Friday in central Gaza. Two children and four women were among the dead.\n\nPalestinians in the border city of Rafah have reported heavy fighting in recent days as Israel's military widened its offensive in the south, seizing control of the entire length of Gaza's border with Egypt. Fighting in Rafah has spurred more than 1 million Palestinians to flee, most of whom had already been displaced earlier in the war. They now seek refuge in makeshift tent camps and other war-ravaged areas, where they lack shelter, food, water and other essentials for survival, the United Nations says.\n\nJoint British-United States airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 42 others, the rebels said Friday. That's the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels' attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza.\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to the Health Ministry, which doesn't distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nIsrael launched its war in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack in which militants stormed into southern Israel, killed some 1,200 people -- mostly civilians -- and abducted about 250. Israel says around 100 hostages are still captive in Gaza, along with the bodies of around 30 more.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Houthi rebels say at least 16 killed and 42 others wounded in joint U.S.-British airstrikes in Yemen\n\n-- Slovenia's government endorses recognition of a Palestinian state\n\n-- A pro-Palestinian camp at Wayne State is dismantled while MIT students walk out of commencement\n\n-- A global aid group asks warring forces to respect its neutrality, saying 24 of its aid workers have been killed\n\nFollow AP's coverage of the war in Gaza at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nTEL AVIV, Israel -- Israel's army said Friday that it completed its mission in part of the Gaza Strip's northern city of Jabaliya and will continue operations in other parts of the enclave.\n\nThe army said during its operations in eastern Jabaliya that it killed hundreds of fighters, destroyed dozens of targets and combat compounds and located hundreds of weapons.\n\nIt also said it destroyed more than 10 kilometers (6 miles) of underground tunnels and retrieved the bodies of seven hostages and returned them to their families in Israel.\n\nIsraeli troops returned to Jabaliya and the surrounding areas in northern Gaza in early May, months after an earlier operation. The United Nations said that about 100,000 Palestinians were displaced in northern Gaza following Israel's evacuation orders.\n\nNorthern Gaza was the first target of Israel's ground offensive launched after Hamas and other militants attacked southern Israel on Oct. 7, killing around 1,200 people.\n\nIsraeli troops have relaunched attacks in the north as Hamas repeatedly returns to areas that Israel withdraws from.\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH -- At least a dozen people were killed, including children, in two airstrikes Friday in Central Gaza, according to hospital officials and Associated Press journalists who counted the bodies.\n\nThe strikes hit Nuseirat and Bureij, two children and four women were among those killed and the bodies were brought to the Al Aqsa Hospital in Deir al-Balah.\n\nA funeral for all 12 people was held Friday.\n\nIsrael's campaign of bombardment and offensives in Gaza has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians and wounded more than 80,000, according to the Gaza Health Ministry. Its count does not differentiate between civilians and combatants.\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates -- Joint British-United States airstrikes targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels killed at least 16 people and wounded 42 others, the rebels said Friday -- the highest publicly acknowledged death toll from the multiple rounds of strikes carried out over the rebels' attacks on shipping.\n\nThe Houthis have stepped up attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, demanding that Israel end the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians there. The war began after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking around 250 hostage.\n\nHouthis said Friday morning that one of the strikes struck a building housing Hodeida Radio and civilian homes in the port city on the Red Sea. Their Al Masirah satellite news channel aired images of one bloodied man being carried downstairs and others receiving aid in the hospital. It said all the dead and nearly all the wounded from the strikes came from there.\n\nThe Houthis described all those killed and hurt in Hodeida as civilians, something The Associated Press couldn't immediately confirm. The rebel force that's held Yemen's capital, Sanaa, since 2014 includes fighters who often are not in uniform.\n\nOther strikes hit outside of Sanaa near its airport and communication equipment in Taiz, the broadcaster said. Little other information was released on those sites -- likely signaling that Houthi military sites had been struck. One person was wounded in Sanaa.\n\nThe U.S. and the U.K. have launched strikes against the Houthis since January. Abdul Malik al-Houthi, the Houthis' secretive supreme leader, offered an overall death toll for the strikes up to that point as 40 people killed and 35 others wounded. He did not offer a breakdown between civilian and combatant casualties at the time.\n\nThe Houthis have launched more than 50 attacks on shipping, killed three sailors, seized one vessel and sunk another since November, according to the U.S. Maritime Administration. This week, they attacked a ship carrying grain to Iran, the rebels' main benefactor.", "source": {"uri": "wral.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WRAL"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": They did not say exactly when the attacks took place and they did not name the two U.S. destroyers they claim to have targeted with drones.\n\nThe Largo Desert is an oil and chemicals tanker sailing under the flag of the Marshall Islands. The Mechela appeared to be a container ship flagged from Portugal. The Minerva Lisa is a crude oil tanker sailing under the flag of Liberia.\n\nThe Houthis claim their piracy is conducted on behalf of the Palestinians in Gaza and they are supposedly targeting ships owned by, or doing business with, Israel and the United States. They have attacked numerous vessels that did not meet any of those criteria, however.\n\nIranian state media quoted Houthi military spokesman Yahya Saree describing the Larego Desert as an \"American\" ship and the Mechela as an \"Israeli\" vessel. He did not elaborate on why the Minerva Lisa was targeted.\n\nRELATED: U.S. Forces Strikes Houthi Targets in Red Sea Show of Defense\n\nMaritime tracking experts noted there does not appear to be a ship named Mechela, or anything close to that name, operating in the Red Sea or Indian Ocean. The Portuguese ship with a similar name, Michela, is currently sailing through the Atlantic Ocean en route to Brazil.\n\nSaree claimed the drone \"hits\" on two American destroyers in the Red Sea were \"accurate.\"\n\nU.S. Central Command (CENTCOM) reported a Houthi anti-ship ballistic missile (ASBM) launch on Saturday with no injuries or damage and a drone launch from Houthi-controlled areas of Yemen on Sunday.\n\nCENTCOM said the uncrewed aerial system (UAS) launched on Sunday was deemed an \"imminent threat to merchant vessels in the region\" and destroyed.\n\n\"This continued malign and reckless behavior by the Iranian backed Houthis threatens regional stability and endangers the lives of mariners across the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden,\" CENTCOM said. The U.S. military offered no further comment on the Houthi claims.\n\nOn Tuesday, UKMTO reported what appears to be another Houthi attack, this one apparently inflicting significant damage on a civilian vessel in the southern Red Sea near Yemen's port city of Hodeidah.\n\nHodeidah is close to the Bab el-Mandeb Strait linking the Red Sea to the Gulf of Aden, an area that has seen many Houthi attacks on shipping.\n\nA maritime security firm called Ambrey picked up radio signals from the stricken vessel, saying that it \"sustained damage to the cargo hold\" and was \"taking on water.\"\n\nThe location of the attack matched up with a Marshall Islands-flagged, Greek-managed bulk carrier called the Laax, which was en route to the United Arab Emirates (UAE).\n\n\"The crew are
